charts.title: Primary Purpose
charts.description: Most respondents self-host for personal purposes.

charts.title: Unique Users
charts.description: Nearly 50% of all setups serve only one to two people.
charts.commentary: Only respondents who selected 'Personal' in the previous question were prompted with this question.

charts.title: Reasons for Self-Hosting
charts.description: Similar to prior years, hobby and privacy remain the top motivators for self-hosting.

charts.title: Hardware Options
charts.description: Pre-built devices and affordable low-powered hardware like the Raspberry Pi are the most popular hardware options due to their simplicity and low cost.

charts.title: Network-Attached Storage
charts.description: NAS devices are most popular among users who self-host for media streaming purposes.

charts.title: Sensitive Data
charts.description: 18% of respondents avoid self-hosting sensitive information for security and backup reasons.

charts.title: Operating Systems
charts.description: Linux-based distributions and platform-specific operating systems are significantly more popular than their counterparts.
charts.commentary: Based on user feedback, an additional question will be included in future surveys allowing users who select 'Linux' to specify their preferred distribution/flavor.

charts.title: Backup Strategies
charts.description: Most users have some form of backup strategy, though 34% store their data in only a single location.

charts.title: Cloud Storage Providers
charts.description: Cloud storage subscriptions are divided between enterprise-level services and widely-used consumer offerings.
charts.commentary: 'Other' consists of providers with fewer than 50 responses, which includes less popular options like Azure, Amazon, and OVH.

charts.title: Container Population
charts.description: Nearly all respondents deploy containers in some capacity.

charts.title: Containers vs Bare Metal
charts.description: Respondents strongly prefer container deployments when the option is available.

charts.title: Container Orchestration
charts.description: Nearly 25% of container users employ orchestration platforms like Kubernetes for deployment.

charts.title: Container Platforms
charts.description: Docker and LXC remain the most common methods for containerization.

charts.title: Management Software
charts.description: Just over half of the respondents who deploy containers use external software to manage them.

charts.title: Management Platforms
charts.description: 82% of respondents use only one of three popular management platforms to deploy containers.
charts.commentary: 'Other' consists of platforms with fewer than 50 responses, which includes less popular options like Arcane, Cloudron, and YunoHost.

charts.title: Update Methodology
charts.description: Respondents tend to avoid automated container updates due to the potential for breaking changes, among other reasons.
charts.commentary: This question was mistakenly deployed as multi-select. Subsequent surveys will limit respondents to a single response.

charts.title: Firewalls
charts.description: Non-ISP firewalls are popular among respondents who cited privacy and control as reasons for self-hosting.

charts.title: Remote Access
charts.description: Respondents predominantly use VPNs and reverse proxies to access services outside their LAN.
charts.commentary: 'Other' consists of platforms with fewer than 50 responses and primarily consists of specific options already captured by the categories above (tunnels, ZeroTier, etc.).

charts.title: Reverse Proxies
charts.description: NGINX and Traefik together (including their various implementations) account for 62% of all reverse proxy usage.
charts.commentary: 'Other' consists of proxies with fewer than 50 responses, which includes less popular options like Zoraxy and Tailscale.

charts.title: Registered Domains
charts.description: 88% of survey respondents use a custom domain to access their services (internally or externally).

charts.title: Domain Registrars
charts.description: Cloudflare is the most popular domain registrar among respondents.
charts.commentary: 'Other' consists of 350+ unique registrars with fewer than 50 responses. While Cloudflare's DNS services are also popular, the survey asked respondents to select Cloudflare only if they had purchased their domain from them.

charts.title: E-mail
charts.description: Given its complexity, most respondents avoid self-hosting e-mail.

charts.title: E-mail Components
charts.description: Sending and receiving are equally popular among respondents.
charts.commentary: 380 respondents self-host both receiving and sending functionality, while only 275 self-host all three.

charts.title: Database Deployment
charts.description: Containerization has made deploying databases trivial and greatly increased their popularity compared to other deployment methods.

charts.title: Media Streaming
charts.description: Jellyfin leads in media streaming, while AudioBookshelf (audiobooks, podcasts) and Navidrome (music) are also popular among respondents.
charts.commentary: 'Other' consists of media servers with fewer than 50 responses, which includes less popular options like Ampache, Subsonic, and Lightweight Media Server.

charts.title: File Storage and Syncing
charts.description: Traditional tools like Nextcloud and Syncthing remain user favorites for managing and accessing files.
charts.commentary: 'Other' consists of platforms with fewer than 50 responses, which includes less popular options like copyparty, FileRun, and system protocols (SMB, NFS, etc.).

charts.title: Authentication
charts.description: Respondents' authentication preferences are divided between legacy identity platforms (Authelia, authentik) and newer solutions (Pocket ID, Pangolin).
charts.commentary: 'Other' consists of platforms with fewer than 50 responses, which includes less popular options like OAuth2 Proxy, Active Directory, and Cloudflare Zero Trust.

charts.title: Note-Taking / Documentation
charts.description: Although popular self-hosted note-taking platforms are available, respondents strongly prefer the functionality of the non-self-hosted Obsidian platform.
charts.commentary: 'Other' consists of platforms with fewer than 50 responses, which includes less popular options like HedgeDoc, Standard Notes, and TiddlyWiki.

charts.title: Git
charts.description: Gitea and Forgejo (a popular fork of Gitea) account for 78% of respondents' deployed Git platforms.
charts.commentary: 'Other' consists of platforms with fewer than 50 responses, which includes less popular options like cgit and vanilla Git.

charts.title: Home Automation
charts.description: 63% of respondents deploy software for smart home or home automation purposes.

charts.title: Game Servers
charts.description: Just 32% of respondents self-host a game server.

charts.title: Games
charts.description: Minecraft is the most popular self-hosted game server, accounting for 37% of responses.

charts.title: Favorite Software
charts.description: This year's list of favorite software span 340 apps across 3,678 responses.
charts.commentary: The chart omits software with fewer than 20 responses, which spans 313 applications across 867 responses.

charts.title: Age Range
charts.description: 88% of respondents are between 20 and 50 years old.

charts.title: Gender
charts.description: Although representation of other genders has increased, males still constitute 94% of respondents.

charts.title: Career Field
charts.description: Self-hosters are more likely to work in technology-related fields.

charts.title: Mobile OS
charts.description: 67% of respondents use Android as their primary mobile OS, while 32% use iOS.
charts.commentary: GrapheneOS (45) was the most popular selection among the 'Other' responses.

charts.title: Donations
charts.description: 59% of respondents have not made a donation to a self-hosted project in the last year.

charts.title: Education
charts.description: Respondents tend to be more educated than the general population.
